gorditachingona: Thank you for sharing this and reminding people to self-check. For years, my older half sister refused to do self-checks and visit a doctor. Fear kept her away. nessa_ellen: I love all of this advice. For me, I rarely ever self checked because I’d get skeeved out by doing it. I’m a cis gendered woman and I don’t have dysmorphia, but I am weirded out by innards so I never did it. Fast forward to 34 years old, I was nursing my youngest and had, what I assumed, was a persistent clogged duct and only that. Nope! LIME SIZED TUMOR!!! So I was dxed with metastatic breast cancer and at 37 I’m still going forward. I’ve had a double mastectomy with no reconstruction and TBH I think it’s not an option that’s pushed enough. Pain is lessened, healing time is lessened. It’s a really good option for those of us that don’t want to add extra, non essential, innards 😅

katieclausen.artist: 1. Allow cancer fighters and survivors to be who ever they wanna be. Don't allow your perception of what "a person going thru this looks like", fuck with OUR days. Shut up about your aunt who had a mole that she thought was cancer for two weeks but it turned out okay. We don't care. 3. Fighters and survivors can do drugs, have sex, be angry, be kind, not want to talk about it, want to talk about it, smoke a pack a day, choose to have chemo, choose not too, it's none of your business. 4. Fault in Our Stars isn't real, cancer doesn't look like this. 5. If you only think about the treatment of cancer in westernised countries you are excluding the majority of cancer suffers. If you want to donate to a charity, donate to the individual like Ericka said, or find somewhere you could put money towards a new MRI machine etc. 6. Global cancer rates are based on statistics where everyone has access to screening and medical care. So they aren't true.

stalking.sarah: For survivors still dealing with bills: @thesamfund gives grants/funds to help young adult survivors (up to age 40, I think!) move on with their lives. It happened to me, I had no choice and I have navigated as anyone in this situation would have to 3) I don't joke about my leg to make other people comfortable, I allow them to sit with their bias. I am funny as hell, but you take my lead. Not your clown 🤡 4) pleasure *is* healing
ruthlesslove88: #13: Cancer is synonymous with evil in the English language. It is not okay to ever suggest let alone think that someone who has cancer brought it upon themselves. We can educate ourselves about the nature of the disease and the ways that the medical industry continues to promote larger systems of oppression that affect our health on the daily.

inkindspace: So agree @valeskapretelt they don’t and they need to know! @ihartericka all that you do is fantastic!
rose_xxi: Thank you from bringing attention to the ways people give .. these large companies like BMW raising awareness about breast cancer are also often the ones creating carcinogens which ultimately causes cancer. All the money fundraise goes towards cure and not prevention, capitalizing off of the illness. So yes, if someone wants to donate they should donate to a person who is battling cancer and not to some fruity fundraising event where survivors are expected to act happy and feel some sort of joy in having battled cancer when it’s one of the single most painful things someone can undergo.

valeskapretelt: Thank you for this. People think they know but they have NO idea. 💜

nnekalynsey: Thank you for #12 sometimes I feel like I’m drowning 💓

janie.egan: Thank you for # 9. Good reminder to keep my personal experience and loss out of the conversation. My loss does not mean that I understand another’s perspective.
lollarossa: Best Breast cancer awareness PSA ever?
eatliftrunyoga: I wish every essential oil MLM seller could see this. I've had 2 friends in recent years be diagnosed, and the amount of people sliding into comments, or DMs looking to sell products is so gross.
lalalala_leslie: What is some more inclusive terminology in place of 'breast? And thank you for your willingness to shine light where there is none.
jmariegray: I feel like I should have known all of this but definitely don't practice it (even with my own mom, a survivor)....THIS IS IMPORTANT AND EDUCATIONAL AND TRUE ASF. As always, you're the best teacher in and out of the classroom
nasdalton: #6 is so legit. A lot of people think they’re helping with large, nationally organized events, or wearing specific colors... a LOT of that money goes to corporate operations and paychecks. I’m not legally allowed to disclose the organization I worked with, but I felt like an asshole by association. Please! If you want to help, ASK a cancer SURVIVOR or someone who is ACTUALLY going through diagnosis, treatment and recovery, how you can help. Don’t blindly donate to an organization just because they’re big or have an iconic logo. Any organization that can fund a legal claim against “copyright” is maybe not being honest about their support of the cause they represent.
chinyereezie: Saw y’all at @joypartybk looking all cute. 🎉🎉
_alenemarie: My grandmother had breast cancer, she noticed a lump in her breast, went the doctor and they told her it was nothing and to come back in six months if it was still there. She came back six months with black liquid coming out of her nipple. Her entire breast was removed. My mom started getting yearly mammograms done as soon as she stopped breastfeeding at 31. Thank you for raising awareness of how to do self exams and thank you for talking specifically about corporations who profit off of this cancer.
elct00: Thanks for showing us how it's done... And I 💖 Whitney. When I was a child I paid $20 to be on the Whitney Houston platinum club card membership.

lovetherainydays: Chemo and varying treatments effect everyone differently. Some people hide it well, some take treatment harder than others. Please be kind, dont ask people when xyz of treatment is going to happen. Let them live without prodding questions.

iolanthe_odile: #3 ! after my dad died of cancer I had a woman stay as a guest in my house telling me how her father in law ate a diet of strawberries and other bullshit and lived another 5 years. 🙄 too much to say to the carer after they’ve just lost a parent

chocolatebarbri: Whew chillay a word. And all Imma add is don’t ever come out your face about what a person does or does not eat as a factor in their cancer diagnosis. 🙄 someone said that to a very close friend and I almost pushed her ass down the stairs and beat her with her own kale.
shestrides: Just had my mammogram today! Such a good thing ❤️
alyssa_jeffers: If you’re unsure of the slightest thing, check it out and ADVOCATE for yourself. I found something, they couldn’t see it on the ultrasound, and they assumed it was nothing serious and sent me on my way. I ignored them and went for a fine needle aspiration of a cyst, and now I have regular appointments with a surgeon to make sure nothing about it changes. Doctors make mistakes - know your body and speak up!!
lauralushoc: I’m going back for a second opinion on one of the lumps in my breast as it’s gotten bigger. Thanks as always for sharing, love you guys, always ✨✨😍✨✨

mogetsmofit: This post is very helpful, thank you!
monicamonfre: The part about not giving it to orgs hit me so hard. When my sister was diagnosed with stage 4 metastatic breast cancer a year ago people rushed to give money to her and her 4 young children (all under 10). A year later and she’s still fighting the fight with new spots appearing daily. But the offers to support financially have dried up. And it’s not just food. It’s gas’s to drive the 2-3 hours weekly for treatment. It’s the cost of child care. So much. And it’s the stories that I can’t take anymore. And the suggestion of what I should do at 42 and BRCA1. I know what the numbers say. But I don’t want another voice in my messages telling me that I need surgeries like yesterday. And the guilt I feel as the older sister who is presenting healthy. The fear I hold that every doctors appointment could tell me something else. A year ago your page was where I headed to for support and information. Thank you for always being a voice that allows for space to just be.
croyster912: Treat someone with cancer like a whole person. More than just their breasts are effected.
